newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PHILIPPINE STOCKS - factors to watch - May 29.
newsitem.headline: PHILIPPINE STOCKS - factors to watch - May 29.

text.p: Following are views on the direction of Philippine stocks on Thursday and main factors likely to affect trading:
* The market will likely correct as investors start to discount first quarter GNP and GDP figures to be released later in the day, Ramon Adviento, analyst at Sun Hung Kai said.
* Traders said profit-taking may be seen due to the continuous rise of the index over the past five sessions.
* Angping & Associates said it is maintaining its recommendation of a trading buy since the market's recent gains have not been supported by volume.
* The National Economic and Development Authority (Neda) said it is set to release first quarter GNP and GDP figures at 1:00 p.m. (0500 GMT).

* Socio-Economic Planning Secretary Cielito Habito said first quarter GNP would be about the same as last year's 6.6 percent, anywhere from six to seven percent, and growth rates in the succeeding quarters would even be stronger.
* Habito said the inflation target for 1997 is now between 5.2 and 5.7 percent compared to an earlier forecast of between 6.0 and 6.5 percent.
* On Wednesday, the Philippine Stock Exchange composite index closed 11.76 points higher for the fifth straight session at 2,722.67.
* The Dow Jones on Wednesday ended 26.18 points lower to 7,357.23. PLDT's ADR dipped $0 1/4 to $56 5/8.
* President Fidel Ramos suggested an extension of a three-year International Monetary Fund programme for the Philippines was possible if Congress fail to pass a crucial tax bill before end-June.
* The Securities and Exchange Commission vowed that it would soon implement new rules and reforms to ensure a more transparent equities market including the establishment of "Chinese walls."
* Petron Corp's market share shrunk to 42.1 percent in the first four months of the year against 42.7 percent in the same period last year, data compiled by oil companies said.
* Two Australian former executives of Marcopper Mining Corp and a Filipino manager pleaded not guilty to charges of causing property damage after mine waste swamped a Philippine river.
* ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corp said that a subsidiary, ABS-CBN Telecom NA Inc, was ready to provide telecommunications services to Filipino communities abroad starting this year.
* Moody's Investor Service upgraded the rating of Bauang Private Power Corp, a unit of First Philippine Holdings Corp, to Ba1 from Ba2 for its $85 million senior secured notes.
* Globe Telecom said it had entered into an agreement with Pacific Gateway Exchange to provide and enhance telecommunications services to Filipino communities in the United States.
* United Paragon Mining Corp said its board has approved a one-for-five stock rights offer.
* Central Bank governor Gabriel Singson said it is offering one-day reverse repos at 16.0 percent and one-day repos at 18.0 percent.
* On Thursday, traders said the Central Bank had cut its overnight borrowing and lending rates by two percentage points each.
* The coupon rate of the Philippines' 10-year Treasury bond fell to 13.875 percent from the previous' auction's 14.125 percent, the Bureau of Treasury said.
* The Philippine peso closed higher at 26.372 to the dollar vs 26.374
* The Philippine interbank call loan average slipped to 18.03125 percent from 18.0625.

* Newspaper BusinessWorld said that the Senate ways and means committee has recommended to tax only income locally generated by foreign corporations and individuals as part of a pending comprehensive tax reform bill.
* Manila Standard said the bidding is set for a 51 percent stake of the government's Food Terminal Inc on June 25.
